Življenja, ki jih je zaznamovala vojna
07 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Petra Mezinec

Tragična usoda primorskih padalcev, ki so jih v pomoč osvobodilnemu gibanju spuščale zavezniške sile, je na Komenskem dobro poznana. Kot vsako leto so tudi letos v komenski knjižnici nekaj dni pred spominsko slovesnostjo za po vojni izginule fante posvetili pozornost novim delom, ki osvetljujejo polpreteklo zgodovino.



Irena Uršič je predstavila zbornik o Ivanu Rudolfu, Ivo Jevnikar pa o družini Čok iz Lonjerja. Foto: Petra Mezinec

KOMEN > Ena osrednjih osebnosti v zgodbi padalcev je bil Ivan Rudolf, ki je v času druge svetovne vojne v Afriki v zavezniških ujetniških taboriščih zbiral prostovoljce za boj proti fašistom in nacistom. Zbornik je ob njegovi 120-letnici rojstva uredila višja kustosinja Muzeja novejše zgodovine Slovenije Irena Uršič, ki je na srečanju v komenski knjižnici predstavila tudi manj izpostavljene dele njegovega življenja. Leta 1898 rojenega Ivana Rudolfa so že kot dijaka v Idriji privlačile preporodovske ideje. Leta 1914 se je skupaj s somišljeniki lotil barvanja nemških napisov, kar je bilo takrat strogo prepovedano. Sledil je zapor v Mitterngrabernu.



Borec za severno mejo
Ko se je vrnil iz zapora, je bil vpoklican v vojsko in poslan na poljsko-rusko mejo. Ob koncu 1. svetovne vojne se je javil in odšel na severno mejo. Deloval je v Ljubljanskem polku in štabu majorja Alfreda Lavriča. Po vojni je zaključil maturo in študij v Nemčiji. Leta 1924 se je vrnil v Gorico. V to obdobje segajo tudi začetki njegovega ilegalnega delovanja v okviru organizacije TIGR. Od leta 1929 do leta 1940 je živel v Ljubljani ter bil ves čas dejaven pri organiziranju emigrantskih društev Primorcev in podobnih aktivnosti.
Dobre stike je imel tudi izven državnih mej. Ko je leta 1939 Nemčija za njim izdala tiralico, je s pomočjo “angleških prijateljev”, kot jih je imenoval v svoji korespondenci, odšel najprej v Beograd, nato v Carigrad in kasneje v Afriko. Tam se začne del njegovega življenja, po katerem je najbolj znan.



Nikoli več se ni vrnil na domača tla
Od leta 1941 je bil tajnik Jugoslovanskega odbora iz Italije, ki si je za cilj postavil priključitev Julijske krajine k Jugoslaviji. Rudolf je bil odgovoren za zbiranje in urjenje vojaške enote. Mnogi med temi fanti, ki jih je novačil v zavezniških ujetniških taboriščih, so nato odšli v prekomorske brigade, nekateri pa so ostali del zavezniške vojske. Najboljše med njimi so izurili za padalce in jih pošiljali v pomoč partizanom. Po vojni je za mnogimi izginila vsaka sled. Natančno število vseh prostovoljcev danes ni znano, kot ocenjuje zgodovinar Gorazd Bajc, pa jih je bilo po vsej verjetnosti med 4500 in 5000.
Tudi po koncu vojne je bilo življenje za Rudolfa težko. Nikoli se ni vrnil v domovino, saj so ga na Nagodetovih procesih označili za izdajalca in agenta tuje obveščevalne službe. Leta 1946 se je z družino preselil v Trst, kjer je še naprej do svoje smrti leta 1962 deloval kot neumorni kulturni delavec, dejaven je bil v politiki, njegov doprinos za slovensko skupnost v povojni Italiji je nenadomestljiv.


Dva nova zbornika osvetljujeta preteklost Primorske.

Trije bratje iz rodbine Čok
Tesen sodelavec in predsednik Jugoslovanskega odbora iz Italije je bil Ivan Marija Čok, ki je izhajal iz ugledne družine Županovih iz Lonjerja pri Trstu. Njihove zgodbe je predstavil Ivo Jevnikar, urednik zbornika Županovi iz Lojnerja, ki so ga ob tej priložnosti predstavili v komenski knjižnici.
Anton Čok (1878-1927) je bil duhovnik in krščanskosocialni delavec, Andrej Čok (1884-1942) je bil učitelj in ravnatelj Ciril-Metodove šole pri Sv. Jakobu v Trstu, Ivan Marija Čok (1886-1948) pa je bil liberalno usmerjen odvetnik, ki je prevzel vodenje Odbora in v marsičem delil Rudolfovo usodo. Tudi on v domovini po vojni ni bil zaželen.
“To je lep primer različno usmerjenih članov iste družine, ki pa so imeli isti cilj: dejansko priznanje dostojanstva vsakega človeka in zatirane slovenske narodne skupnosti. Predstavljali so tudi tri nekdanje in še vedno nezamenljive stebre pri ohranjanju in razvoju narodne manjšine: šolo in kulturno delo, cerkev ter narodnopolitično delo.”
Primorskih padalcev se bodo spomnili v ponedeljek ob 11. uri s spominsko slovesnostjo ob Fakinovi domačiji v Škrbini. Letošnji slavnostni govornik bo zgodovinar Blaž Torkar.

The lives marked by war
07 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Petra Mezinec

The tragic fate of the coastal parachutists descended by the Allied forces in support of the liberation movement is well known in Komensky. Like every year, a few days before the memorial ceremony for the post-war boys, the Comenius Library paid attention to new works that illuminate past history.



Irena Ursic presented a collection on Ivan Rudolf and Ivo Jevnikar on the Čok family from Lonjer. Photo by Petra Mezinec

KOMEN> One of the central figures in the parachute story was Ivan Rudolf, who, during the Second World War in Africa, had been recruiting volunteers to fight fascists and Nazis in Allied captive camps. At his 120th birthday, the collection was edited by Senior Curator of the Museum of Contemporary History Irena Uršič, who also presented the less exposed parts of his life at a meeting at the Comenius Library. Ivan Rudolf, born in 1898, was already attracted to revival ideas as a student in Idrija. In 1914, he and his associates began painting German inscriptions, which was strictly forbidden at the time. A prison in Mitterngrabern followed.



A fighter for the northern border
When he returned from prison, he was called up to the army and sent to the Polish-Russian border. At the end of World War I, he volunteered and went to the northern border. He worked at the Ljubljana Regiment and the headquarters of Major Alfred Lavric. After the war he completed his matriculation and study in Germany. In 1924 he returned to Gorizia. The beginnings of his illegal activities within TIGR also date back to this period. From 1929 to 1940 he lived in Ljubljana and was constantly active in organizing the emigrant societies of the Littoral and similar activities.
He also had good contacts outside national borders. When Germany issued a warrant for him in 1939, with the help of "English friends", as he called them in his correspondence, he first went to Belgrade, then to Constantinople and later to Africa. That is where the part of his life that he is best known for begins.



He never returned to home soil again
From 1941 he served as secretary of the Yugoslav Committee of Italy, aiming to annex the Julian region to Yugoslavia. Rudolf was responsible for the collection and training of the military unit. Many of these guys, whom he recruited to Allied captive camps, then went to overseas brigades, and some remained part of the Allied army. The best of them were trained in paratroopers and sent to assist the partisans. After the war, every trace disappeared for many. The exact number of all volunteers is not known today, according to historian Gorazd Bajc, but there are likely to be between 4,500 and 5,000.
Even after the end of the war, life was difficult for Rudolf. He never returned home, as he was identified as a traitor and a foreign intelligence agent on Nagodet's processes. In 1946 he moved with his family to Trieste, where he continued to work as a tireless cultural worker until his death in 1962, he was active in politics, his contribution to the Slovenian community in post-war Italy is irreplaceable.


Two new collections shed light on Primorska's past.

Three brothers from the Chok family
A close associate and chairman of the Yugoslav Committee of Italy was Ivan Marija Čok, who came from a distinguished family of Županovs from Lonjer near Trieste. Their stories were presented by Ivo Jevnikar, editor of the Proceedings of the Mayors of Lojner and presented at the Comenius Library on this occasion.
Anton Čok (1878-1927) was a priest and Christian-social worker, Andrej Čok (1884-1942) was a teacher and headmaster of the Ciril-Method School at Sv. Jacob in Trieste, and Ivan Marija Čok (1886-1948) was a liberal-minded lawyer who took over the management of the Committee and shared in many ways Rudolf's fate. He was also not desirable in his homeland after the war.
“This is a fine example of differently oriented members of the same family, who, however, had the same goal: the actual recognition of the dignity of each person and the oppressed Slovenian national community. They also represented the three former and still irreplaceable pillars in the preservation and development of a national minority: school and cultural work, the church and national political work. ”
Maritime paratroopers will be remembered on Monday at 11 a.m. with a memorial service at the Fakin Homestead in Škrbina. This year's keynote speaker will be historian Blaž Torkar.
